questions.question: 1. Which of the following is an array?

explanations.a: All the elements are of the same type (integer).
explanations.b: This option contains a mix of different types such as integers and strings.
explanations.c: This option contains a mix of different types such as boolean values and strings.
explanations.d: This option contains a mix of different types such as integers and boolean values.

questions.question: 2. Which of the following is an array sorted in ascending order?

explanations.a: -10 must appear at the beginning and not the end as it is the smallest element.
explanations.b: -10 and -13 must be swapped as -13 is smaller than -10 and not vice versa.
explanations.d: This sequence is in descending order and must be reversed.

questions.question: 3. Which of the following is not a sorting algorithm?

explanations.a: This is a popular sorting algorithm which is covered by this very experiment.
explanations.b: Another popular sorting algorithm that can be learnt from the following link
explanations.c: Another popular sorting algorithm that can be learnt from the following link
explanations.d: Binary search is not a sorting algorithm but is in fact an algorithm to search for a specific element in a sorted array.

questions.question: 4. Consider the following array: A = [-1, 9, 4, 8] Identify A[2], i.e, the element with index 2 from the following (assume 0-indexed array).

explanations.a: Array indexing begins at 0 and this is the 0th element, i.e, A[0].
explanations.b: Array indexing begins at 0 and this is the element with index 1, i.e, A[1].
explanations.c: Array indexing begins at 0 and this is the element with index 2, i.e, A[2].
explanations.d: Array indexing begins at 0 and this is the element with index 3, i.e, A[3].

questions.question:
5. Consider the following pseudo-code:
for i = 0 to 2
  for j = 0 to i
    print “*”
  print newline
end
Predict the output of the above code.

explanations.a: The code makes use of nested loops to print 3 lines where each line prints the same number of asterisks as the line number as per indexing starting at 1. The number of asterisks is controlled via the inner/nested j loop by setting the maximum limit on the values j can take on and looping through the same starting at 0.
explanations.b: This output does not take into account the nested/inner j loop where a variable number of asterisks is printed per line depending on the line number/index.
explanations.c: This output assumes a reverse order where the number of asterisks (limit of j’s value) per line is calculated as (3 - i) where i is the line number/index in accordance with 0 indexing.
explanations.d: This output fails to take into account the printing of a newline after each iteration of the outer i loop.
